column1: De Pere (pronounced locally as "dee-PEER") is a city located in Brown County
column4: 970 according to U.S. Census Bureau estimates in 2019. De Pere is part of the Green Bay Metropolitan Statistical Area.

column1: At the arrival of the first European
column4: De Pere was the site of a polyglot settlement of several thousand attracted by the fishing at the first rapids of the Fox River. In 1671 French Jesuit explorer Père Claude-Jean Allouez founded the St. Francis Xavier Mission at the last set of rapids on the Fox River before it enters The Bay of Green Bay. The site was known as Rapides Des Pères (rapids of the fathers) which became modern day De Pere.Originally De Pere consisted solely of the community on the east side of the river; however
column5: in 1890 the City of West De Pere
column6: on the west side of the river
column7: consolidated with the city of De Pere to form a single community.

column2: which abuts the banks of the Fox River on the city's west side near the Claude Allouez Bridge
column3: was founded by Norbertine Abbot Pennings in 1898.

column1: De Pere has several areas on the National Register of Historic Places. North Broadway Street Historic District is listed as #83003368. Large homes line Broadway
column8: and Wisconsin Streets near the Fox River.The De Pere Lock and Dam Historic District (#93001331) was added in 1993.The Randall Avenue Historic District was added in 2007.

column1: De Pere is represented by Mike Gallagher (R) in the United States House of Representatives
column2: and by Ron Johnson (R) and Tammy Baldwin (D) in the United States Senate. Robert Cowles (R) and Dave Hansen (D) represent De Pere in the Wisconsin State Senate
column5: and John Macco (R) represent De Pere in the Wisconsin State Assembly.

column1: De Pere has a mayor-council form of government. The mayor is also elected. The city council consists of eight alderpersons
column2: two elected from each of four districts. All elected officials serve two-year terms.

column1: De Pere is served by two school districts.
The Unified School District of De Pere has the following schools:
Altmayer Elementary SchoolThe School District of West De Pere has the following schools:
Phantom Knight Charter SchoolDe Pere private schools:
Our Lady of LourdesDe Pere is also home to St. Norbert College
column2: a private Roman Catholic liberal arts college.

column1: Syble Hopp is a school for children ages 3–21 years old who have cognitive and other developmental disabilities. It is operated by the Brown County Children with Disabilities Education Board.
St. Mark Lutheran Church is a member of the Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod in De Pere.The National Shrine of Saint Joseph is located at St. Norbert College.
St. Norbert Abbey is the mother canonry of the Premonstratensian Order in the United States.

Interstate 41 travels north–south on the west side of De Pere. Wisconsin Highway 32/Wisconsin Highway 57 enter De Pere from the south and split in the middle of De Pere. WIS 32 heads east–west through De Pere before turning north. WIS 57 continues straight north. There is limited transit service operated by Green Bay Metro and the CN provides freight railroad service. The Fox River is navigable for boat and canoe traffic with the exception of a dam.
